title.rendered: What are Financial Frauds and how to prevent them?

content.rendered:
An fraud financial or a financial fraud is a crime against the property of an estate. They usually occur in an economic environment, causing monetary losses to companies, investors and employees. There are multiple types of fraud, among the most common are:

  • The cancellation of collected invoices and sale of services that are not declared in taxes.
  • Salary payments to personnel who do not work or have any kind of employment relationship with the company.

This type of malicious acts have generated disastrous consequences in both large and medium-sized and small companies.

Many companies do not know that they have been victims of fraud and have lived with it, the lack of internal controls can lead a company to have or generate embezzlements either asset embezzlement (divert funds for private or private purposes). But not only these problems affect the financial, but also many other moral aspects in the organization and the ethics that are handled in each one of them.

Does the size of the company affect to be prone to fraud?

The size of the company does not matter. –Fraud does not recognize sizes-, this can be presented in large, medium and small companies, even it does not recognize geographical locations, both national and international companies can be victims, all of them can be the object of fraud at any time. In small companies, the impact of fraud is greater, since they generally do not invest in their internal control areas. What allows a greater possibility of suffering at any time a financial scam.

The fraud detection has become a true feat because the person who commits it has possibly already identified certain elements or weaknesses within the company. Mainly, it is because that person identifies some kind of opportunity to commit such fraud. The individual analyzes internally if there is no supervision or any type of regulation in the company that can stop him. This is known as –Fraud opportunity triangle-.

How does fraud impact businesses financially?

The first impact is fraud amount, this action will cause economic damage to the company, since what is most harmed there is the capital of the company and its partners. The second are the costs that are associated with this fraud, if the company goes to specialists to carry out forensic audits to detect or discover the totality of the fraud, gathering the necessary evidences to later specify the cause of this, are additional costs in which the company must cover.

Lastly, it is the reputational costis the most difficult to overcome given that the clients that the company currently manages and, in case they detect some irregularities, they will possibly begin to look at the other competitors and in effect this will cause their loss of prestige.

The reputational impact It is the one that manages to have the greatest weight, it is negative before society, employees and workers. Shareholders can make radical decisions such as not to continue investing in that company, simply because they see a risk.

The culture of permissibility in companies should not be markedespecially if the one who allows it is the owner himself, because this can lead to employees intending to apply misconduct.

You have to have a code of ethics within the company, in this way the employees will know first-hand what the ethical and professional operation of the organization is like. Thus, through active participation, it will be possible to establish a healthy environment within it.

The business fraud they can be perpetrated by both insiders and outsiders. There is an idea that only within companies is where most frauds are committed, but the truth is that some internal employees of the company can collude with external people to commit some type of fraud. fraud.

Making a risk matrix prevents illegal activities in the company.

The more vulnerable the control system within companies, it is more likely to suffer an event of these characteristics. Each organization should have its own core, where what is sought is to be monitoring which are those sensitive activities internally within the organization. It is through systems or digital applications with which they allow the monitoring and prevention of fraud, it is an essential mechanism to take into account for the organizational management.

In general, within the priorities of companies, the implementation of anti-fraud control mechanisms, the priority has always been sales as well as production, cost reduction and business expansion. Investing in internal controls and acquiring technological tools for the prevention and detection of illicit activities should be a priority rather than an expense.

Most common financial fraud in companies

The Staff selection It is a key management that all companies should implement when hiring, where not only their knowledge is evaluated, but also their moral values ​​and professional ethics to avoid fraud. We will explain some of the most common:

  • computer fraud: They can be generated through emails, where what is sought is to steal personal data such as bank details. Some of them are malware Y phishing.
  • identity theft: It is about taking the personal data of the credit card holder and pretending to be that person to make some type of purchase or bank transaction.
  • document fraud: This fraud occurs when the employee presents an invoice or a ticket that does not meet the conditions to be considered valid within the statutes of the organization.
  • Chronological fraud: This is a type of internal fraud in which the expenses presented by the employee do not meet the limits set by the company’s travel policies.
  • Articles purchase: In these cases, the infraction is committed when the employee acquires a product without authorization from the company, it can range from a cell phone charger to equipment of greater economic value.
  • Presentation of the expense after the deadline: This is a fraud where the employee submits his expense notes or invoices after the deadline established by the company.
  • The manipulation of social capital and patrimony: It is generally carried out by resource administrators and with abuse of positions of trust.
  • Intentional information leak: This leak may be about the technology used by the company, about its transactions, services and products.
  • Illicit Appropriation: It can be of money, goods or values.

How to prevent fraud?

Prevention It is the most important thing for any company, because anyone could enter from a computer and to hack all the information to later be fraudulently manipulated and commit any type of fraud.

exist millions of ways to commit crimes fraudulently. It is important to have protection measures against fraud.

Below you can find anti-fraud measures that can serve you and your company as a control mechanism:

  • Carrying out internal and external audits and controls.
  • Implementation of business ethics codes.
  • Information access controls.
  • Detailed definition of tasks, roles, responsibilities, positions, etc.
  • Job rotation.
  • Periodic and surprise controls.
  • Have informants among the staff.
  • Training programs.
  • Selectivity and background check of the personnel hired and contracted.
  • Maintain an ethical code to avoid fraud.

There is a well-known term to determine the three main impacts or reasons that can lead someone to commit fraud, it is known as “Fraud Diamond” and is classified as follows:

  • The opportunity: It is about finding the right moment to commit the fraud, knowing exactly all the weaknesses of the company.
  • The pressure: This behavior can be seen reflected when the employee is deposited with the vote of confidence so that he has in his possession tokens or financial keys, where you can make some type of transaction to your bank account.
  • Rationalization: Are those thoughts and impulses that are generated from the mind of the person to get to commit a fraud. A very common idea that can haunt a person’s mind is “I deserve it”, “they didn’t raise my salary”, “I don’t have how to pay my debts”.

Fraud never stops growing! It is necessary to invest in digital applications for the control, prevention and mitigation of its negative impact on the organization.
